teacher-test.title: Tea Time
teacher-test.subtitle: Mobile Learning App for Elementary Teacher Certification
teacher-test.description: Tea Time is a mobile learning app designed for pre-service teachers preparing for the Korean elementary teacher certification exam. It helps candidates study the vast curriculum anytime, anywhere through quiz-based learning, while systematically managing incorrect answers to bring them closer to success. Built with Flutter, the app is designed to allow efficient learning of key content during commute times or short breaks.

overview.introduction: A mobile study tool for teacher certification, providing curriculum-based questions and error management
overview.features: Curriculum/General Theory tests, Wrong Answer Notes

0.subtitle: Main Screen Features
0.caption: Main Screen
0.0: The main screen was designed to motivate learning by displaying the countdown to the exam date and test results. Exam dates are calculated based on the weekday of November 1st: if it falls on a Sunday, the exam is set for the 7th; otherwise, the next Saturday is calculated from the weekday of the 1st. Wrong answers are managed in Firestore, with each incorrect question and timestamp uploaded after a test. On other devices, data is synchronized if the locally stored timestamp is outdated.

2.subtitle: Managing Multi-dimensional Arrays
2.caption: Multi-dimensional Array Management
2.0: To display and test the curriculum content table, each value needed to be componentized. Rendering also varied by grade cluster. To handle this, I implemented a multi-dimensional array structured as Subject > Grade Group > Domain > Category > Detail. This made function implementation simpler and allowed additional detail to be included when implementing the wrong answer notes.

3.subtitle: Answer Comparison
3.caption2: Comparison of Original vs. User‚Äôs Answer
3.0: Since identifying errors at the sentence level takes time, enabling users to see exactly where mistakes occurred helped reduce time when reviewing answers. I implemented character-by-character comparison with and without spacing considered, and highlighted incorrect parts with a red background. This significantly improved the user experience in error review.

0.2: Provided automatic wrong-answer recording and re-learning flow
0.3: Backed up error lists using Firebase

1.1: Gained deeper understanding of complexity in data segmentation and multi-dimensional arrays
1.2: Improved knowledge of cross-platform app design
